awd_titl_txt: Magneto-mechanical Sensors and Actuators for Platelet Biomechanics under Flow
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the physics of blood clotting. It will elucidate the role of platelet forces and viscoelasticity during clot formation and will establish a translational tool that can generate biomechanical-specific data on platelets. The project will enable a greater understanding of the coagulation process beyond the classical coagulation cascade. It will not only advance the fields of hemostasis and thrombosis, but also biomechanics, nanomaterials, and nanomagnetics. The educational plan focuses on integrating research concepts into courses on biomechanics at the awardee's institution as well as organizing K-12 and undergraduate outreach events that focus on research opportunities. The research and educational plans provide training experience for future generations in nanoscale biomechanics and biotechnology by involving graduate students and undergraduate students in the research.

The research objective of this award is to develop a microfluidic platform that can test the biomechanical properties of platelets and measure their contractile forces during clotting. Platelets are the smallest cells in the human body, but are indispensable in hemostasis. In clot formation, the platelet cytoskeleton is necessary for changing cell shape and for producing actin-myosin forces. The first task of this award will work to fabricate strong magnetic nanowires by increasing the size and improving the composition of the nanowires. The second task will work to embed nanowires into microposts inside a microfluidic device so that an external magnetic field can be used to apply forces to platelets. The third task will work to build nanoscale magnetometers underneath each magnetic micropost to measure their deflection by platelet forces.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a novel microfluidic platform that measures platelet forces and tests their biomechanical properties using magnetic microposts. Platelets are the smallest cells in the human body, but they are indispensable for blood coagulation. Platelets use their ability to generated force through actin-myosin interactions to form a strong plug at the site of vascular injury. Previous research tools for platelets are not able to measure platelet forces and their biomechanical properties. Consequently, there is an incomplete understanding of the role of platelet biomechanics in hemostasis.

To address this shortcoming, a microfluidic device was developed that exposes whole blood to shear flow using a microchannel containing an array of microscale, silicone blocks and flexible posts. The blocks cause a local shear gradient and are coated with extracellular matrix proteins to initiate the adhesion and activation of platelets in the blood. Flexible posts are situated behind each of the blocks. The posts are deflected towards the blocks by the contractile forces generated by platelets. Iron microparticles are embedded into the silicone during the soft lithography process to give the posts have magnetic properties. The magnetic posts are actuated with an external magnetic field to oscillate the post for biomechanical testing. To sense platelet forces, giant magnetoresistive (GMR) sensors are placed underneath the device to detect the movement of the magnetic post. The outcomes of this project led to novel technology, journal publications, patents, training of engineers, and participation in outreach activities,

The intellectual merit of this project concentrated on magneto-mechanical systems and biomechanical research. A novel magneto-mechanical force sensor was developed that uses embedded magnetic material to determine the force generated by platelets in real time, without the need for an optical microscope or image analysis. The novel force sensor enables the tool to be used in clinical settings and generate more data on how platelets generate force while using multiple agonists. The knowledge gained by this work improves the fields of hemostasis, thrombosis, biomechanics, nanomaterials, magnetics, and the interaction of multiple systems.

The broader impacts of this project had wide reaching contributions to multiple research fields and in training new engineers and scientists. Specifically, a better understanding of platelet biomechanics can improve the medical treatment of trauma, atherosclerosis, stroke, deep-vein thrombosis, and acute myocardial infarctions. The work generated a greater understanding of the role of platelet contractile forces in hemostasis and thrombosis by developing a novel means of applying forces to platelets. In this project, there was an emphasis on the training of future generations in nano-biomechanics and nano-biotechnology by involving both graduate students and undergraduate students in the research. Lastly, the project had impact in engineering education and outreach efforts through participation in several events each year.


Last Modified: 07/10/2018
Modified by: Nathan J Sniadecki
